projects.title: SDGP project increased maize value chain efficiency in Rwanda
projects.description:
Africa Improved Foods (AIF) produces fortified foods for infants and breast-feeding women in Rwanda and aims to source at least 50% of its raw materials domestically. However, at present the poor quality of local maize (aflatoxin contamination) prevents the company to reach its objective. The project aims to eliminate aflatoxin from Rwanda’s maize value chain by making the value chain more efficient. This will lead to improved food quality, less postharvest losses, increased farmer incomes and reduced malnutrition.

Responsible for project design and development. Value € 6 million, subsidy € 3 million for 5 years. Consortium: DSM (Africa Improved Foods), Kumwe, Agriterra, Sight and Life and Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources of Rwanda.

projects.title: SDGP project increased potato value chain efficiency in the Great Lakes Region
projects.description:
This project’s goal is to create a well-connected and efficient seed and ware potato value chain in Rwanda’s Great Lakes Region. In order to reduce efficiencies, lack of coordination and the weak linkage between the seed and ware potato value chain farmers will be provided with improved agricultural practices, climate change adaptation and business development skills. In addition, investments will be made through the seed and potato value chain, such as storage, logistics, energy and access to finance. As a result, 20,000 potato farmers will increase their productivity by using clean seeds. Furthermore, the project will provide training, access to finance and create market opportunities by further developing the processing capacity.

Project design and development. Value: € 5 million, subsidy € 2.5 million for 4 years. Consortium of Delphy, Hollanda Fairfoods, Agriterra, Seed Potato Fund and the Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources of Rwanda.

projects.title: Hortinvest
projects.description:
The HortInvest project aims to increase farmers’ incomes, grow the relative contribution of the horticultural sector to the regional economy in North West Rwanda, and improve the food and nutrition security of the targeted households. HortInvest will help realise the Rwandan National Horticulture Policy to create fast economic growth, and reduce poverty and malnutrition. The project covers six target districts in North-west Rwanda.

HortInvest has four components, aligned with Rwanda’s National Horticultural Policy:

Production for domestic and regional markets
Food & Nutrition security improvement
Supply chains for export markets
Strengthening the enabling environment

The project budget is €16.2 million, with an additional minimum of € 5.0 million co-funding by private sector partners in the project. The project will reach at least 44,000 farmer households in six districts in North West Rwanda. The consortium exists out of SNV, IDH, Agriterra, WUR and Holland Greentech.

projects.title: Feasibility study Development of an Export Growth Facility in Rwanda
projects.description: Feasibility study for the German Development Bank KfW concerning the design and development of an Export Growth Facility in Rwanda. KfW aimed to stimulate commercial Rwandan banks to provide exporting SMEs with export finance products. After doing a market assessment, identifying gaps and opportunities, we presented KfW with a number of possible financial instrumental interventions for the new facility.

projects.title: Set-up of the Agribusiness Capital Fund Technical Assistance Facility
projects.description:
The International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) has created a new $60 million fund to de-risk investments of small loans in agriculture value chains in Africa. The Agribusiness Capital Fund, or ABC Fund — with contributions from the European Commission, Luxembourg, Africa, Caribbean, and the Pacific group of states, and AGRA — seeks to mobilize about $240 million in private capital. The organisation recognized a lack of financing to build the types of businesses that will help rural communities process their crops and link them to markets and has created the ABC fund to address this issue.

The ABC Fund, which is managed independently by Bamboo Capital Partners in collaboration with Injaro Investments, provides loans of between $25,000 and $1 million to small businesses in order to address the “missing middle” of finance between microfinance and commercial loans. 

To ensure that the financing for these SMEs and cooperatives (direct financing) and financial institutions (indirect financing) has the desired impact on rural communities, IFAD has selected Agriterra to manage its Technical Assistance Facility. In a consortium with Rabo Partnerships, Agricord and Advance Consulting, Agriterra coordinates this TA facility.

As program manager I was responsible for the set-up of the TA facility, development of management procedures and first trials of combined due diligence and TA-assessment missions at SMEs and cooperatives in Ghana and Ivory Coast.

profile_positions.description: Management of the portfolio and regional cooperative development teams of Agriterra in the African Great Lakes Region.
profile_positions.title: Regional manager African Great Lakes Region

profile_positions.description:
Business advisor and team coordinator for cooperative businesses in Rwanda, Burundi and DRC, based in Kigali, Rwanda. 

Agriterra is the cooperative development expert for agricultural cooperatives in developing countries and is in the Great Lakes Region successfully part of multiple Public Private Partnerships in international food systems. Cooperatives are robust business entities that serve the interest of their members while adding value to agricultural produce and responding to market developments. In both domestic and international value chains cooperatives have the potential to reach economies of scale and through proper due diligence Agriterra's Great Lakes team has managed to partner with the 100 agricultural cooperatives with the highest growth potential in the Great Lakes Region.

Agriterra's approach is geared towards making cooperatives bankable, by reinforcing three fundamental aspects of cooperative businesses: business development, governance and financial management. Currently we provide our advisory services to agricultural cooperatives in the value chains of horticulture, maize, coffee, dairy, rice, cassava and potatoes. Additionally we have partnered with cooperative banks to strengthen the ability of farmer organisations to access finance.

Since 2016 we created a team of 25 professional business advisors and set up 5 offices in Rwanda, Burundi and Congo. We support congolese rice cooperatives supplying the Heineken brewery in Bukavu, we support coffee cooperatives in moving away from the commodity market and towards the specialty coffee markets in Europe and the USA, we are in multi-national consortia with players as DSM, SNV, IDH and Wageningen University and most importantly: we are making an impact on the lives of more than 100,000 farmers.
profile_positions.title: Business Advisor

profile_positions.description:
The Ignite Fund is a growth capital investment fund operating in several post conflict countries. Ignite Fund was launched by the Dutch NGO SPARK in 2014. 

IGNITE Fund provides loan, convertible debt, equity and quasi equity investments of € 100,000 - € 750,000 to SMEs with growth potential. As Investment Manager for Rwanda and Burundi I am responsible for identifying promising companies, business screening, due diligence and developing the business case. After getting approval from our Investment Committee in London/Amsterdam, we take an equity share into the targeted company and hence I have my seat on the Board of Directors.
profile_positions.title: Investment Manager Rwanda

profile_positions.description: Creating linkages between Dutch and Rwandan companies in order to stimulate knowledge transfer, business linkages, trade and investments. I am available as focal point for entrepreneurs looking to explore the Dutch or Rwandan market and I am involved in the organization of trade missions between the two countries.
profile_positions.title: Business to Business Manager Kigali, Rwanda

profile_positions.description:
Consultant Innovation Projects at Subvention BV. 

Subvention is a grant consultancy company based in Enschede, Zwolle, Uden and Gouda and works for a variety of clients in the Netherlands. Subvention is specialized in acquiring grants, designing and managing projects and partnerships and accesses grants on European level, at national governmental ministries, at provincial governments and private funding agencies.

As Consultant in Innovation Projects, I have successfully applied for funding for the realization of major innovative projects in the field of:

•	innovative ship-building,
•	processing technique development,
•	renewable energy,
•	product and machinery development.

After acquiring assignments like these, I was responsible for the creation of successful project proposals, designing the projects and creating partnerships in order to realize objectives. With project management activities I guided the SMEs from the beginning until the end of their project.
profile_positions.title: Consultant Innovation Projects
